title: PhysicsDataPlayground
text:
Caution



This is a draft version of the website and does not represent the final content. You can email suggestions to Russell Almond.
This file contains data from the IES project Physics Playground

title: PhysicsDataPlayground
text:
Support:
This report is based on research supported by Institute of Education Sciences, U.S. Department of Education to Florida State University.

“Exploring adaptive cognitive and affective learning support for next-generation STEM learning games.” (Institute of Education Sciences award no. R305A170376, Val Shute and Russell Almond, PIs)

Additional support (for previous version of Physics Playground and the Peanut and Proc4 scoring engines) was provided by:

‘Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation grant “Games as Learning/Assessment: Stealth Assessment” (no. 0PP1035331, Val Shute, PI)’,
‘National Science Foundation grant “DIP: Game-based Assessment and Support of STEM-related Competencies” (no. 1628937, Val Shute, PI)’,
‘National Science Foundation grant “Mathematical Learning via Architectual Design and Modeling Using E-Rebuild.” (no. 1720533, Fengfeng Ke, PI)’,

The opinions express are those of the authors and do not represent views of any of the sponsoring agencies.

title: About

About this site

title: Pretest and Posttest
text:
Near and Far Transfer
Form A
Form B

title: Pretest and Posttest
text:
Form A and Form B

Form A Pretest – This consisted of all Form A items, and was used as the pretest for the Affective Support Study.

PDF of Form A

ECT Posttest – This consisted of all Form A ECT items, both near and far transfer. Due to a mix-up while constructing the forms, the Near POT items were also presented to the students but not included in the score. This was given on Day 3 or 5 of the Affective Support Study, depending on study condition.

ECT Posttest

POT Posttest – This consisted of all Form A ECT items, both near and far transfer. This was given on Day 3 or 5 of the Affective Support Study, depending on study condition.

POT Posttest

title: Pretest and Posttest
text:
Use during the studies
In the Affective Support Study, the students received all Form A items, ECT and POT and Near and Far, on the first day (Monday) of the study before starting game play.
Students in Groups A, C and F played the ECT levels on Tuesday and Wednesday, taking the ECT posttest, both Near and Far items on Wednesday during the last 20 minutes of the class period. Then on Thursday and Friday, these groups played the POT game levels on Thursday and Friday and took the POT posttest on Friday.
Students in Groups B, D, and E reversed the ordering of the ECT and POT levels. Playing POT game levels on Tuesday and Wednesday, taking the POT posttest on Wednesday, playing ECT game levels on Thursday and Friday, and taking the ECT posttest on Friday.
Due to a mix-up during the construction of the post-test for the Affective Support Study, Form A items were used for both the pretest and posttest. At least two days of gameplay occured between the two uses.

title: Event Logs
section: Table of known verbs and objects
text:
Table of known verbs and objects
The master list of levels: <Data/LevelData.csv>
The list of all verb–object pairs: <Data/EventTable.csv>

Object List

objectList <- c("game level", "silverWin", "game object", "learning support",
                "goldWin", "newPurchase", "newMoneyEarned", "replayButton",
                "game (Physics Playground)", "ball", "footBall",
                "billiardStripeBall", "glossary", "definition", "golfBall",
                "formula", "module")
objectList

 [1] "game level"                "silverWin"                
 [3] "game object"               "learning support"         
 [5] "goldWin"                   "newPurchase"              
 [7] "newMoneyEarned"            "replayButton"             
 [9] "game (Physics Playground)" "ball"                     
[11] "footBall"                  "billiardStripeBall"       
[13] "glossary"                  "definition"               
[15] "golfBall"                  "formula"                  
[17] "module"                   




Object Type
These are the values of the gemeObjectType [sic] field, indicating the type of object from the object classification system.

objectTypes <- c("freeform", "Ramp", "Lever", "ball", "pin", "Pendulum",
                 "Springboard","Weight")
objectTypes

[1] "freeform"    "Ramp"        "Lever"       "ball"        "pin"        
[6] "Pendulum"    "Springboard" "Weight"

The raw JSON data is available at https://pluto.coe.fsu.edu/PhysicsPlayground/data/IES2022-AllP4Events.json.gz
The filtered data containing only “interesting” events is at: https://pluto.coe.fsu.edu/PhysicsPlayground/data/PPIES2022-P4Filtered.json.gz
Both files are compressed using gnu zip (gzip)

title: Physics Playground Overview
text:
Video Overview 
Physics Playground Short Film: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HqIY9x5dUf0


Use the following links for the game:

Version 1: With Store: http://35.196.157.53/pp/wstore/demo.html
Version 2: Without Store: http://35.196.157.53/pp/game/demo.html
Level Editor: http://35.196.157.53/pp/editor/demo.html
Username: demo2
Password: demo2pass
















Video 1. The sketching level “Caveman.” The path of the green ball is blocked by a wooden club. To solve the level, players need to draw a lever to lift the wooden club that blocks the path.
Caveman Setup Figure 1. The sketching level “Caveman.” The path of the green ball is blocked by a wooden club.
Caveman Solution Figure 2. Worked example of the sketching level “Caveman.” To solve the level, players need to draw a lever to lift the wooden club that blocks the path.
https://youtu.be/qiYtPngpUpA





Video 2. The manipulation level “Cookie Monster.” In the level, mass and gravity are set to default levels, air resistance is medium, the static blower is in full force, and bounciness is available. To make the ball hit the balloon, players need to reduce air resistance and gravity and enable bounciness.
Cookie Monster Start
Figure 3. The manipulation level “Cookie Monster.” In the level, mass and gravity are set to default levels, air resistance is medium, the static blower is in full force, and bounciness is available.
Cookie Monster Solution
Figure 4. Worked example of the manipulation level “Cookie Monster.” To make the ball hit the balloon, players need to reduce air resistance and gravity and enable bounciness.
https://youtu.be/K7trh3Gkuug

title: Affective Support Data
text:
The complete data are available in the following formats:

Comma Separated Value
SPSS Save file



This data subset contains just the data from the pretest and posttest questionnaires.
Posttest columns are marked with either .ect or .pot depending on which posttest the items appear on. Note that students received the ECT and POT tests on Wednesday or Friday of the study week depending on their treatment group.
Pre, Post Data



These data contain information on how the learning supports were played. * Timestamp_XXX – These give the time at which the level was played. * TrophyLevel_XXX – what trophy the player earned. This can be gold, silver, quit or missing. The quit indicates that the player attempted the level but did not earn a trophy. * NumberAttempts_XXX – The number of attempts the player made for this game level.
Note that the player may have attempted each level several times. There are two versions of this data file, one showing the values related to the first level and one to the last levels. In the full data set the suffixes .first and .last are added to the column names to indicate which version is used.

Observables, First Attempt
Observables, Last Attempt




This is data about the usage of the learning supports.
Learning Support



This provides scores from the Bayesian Network model, which probabilities for the nine nodes in the competency model. For each none, there are three columns giving the marginal probability of the High, Medium and Low proficiency respectively. The EAP (expected a posteriori) scores are produced by assigning Low=-1, Medium=0 and High=1 and calculating the expected value.
Bayesian Network Scores



The raw JSON data is available at https://pluto.coe.fsu.edu/PhysicsPlayground/data/IES2022-AllP4Events.json.gz
The filtered data containing only “interesting” events is at: https://pluto.coe.fsu.edu/PhysicsPlayground/data/PPIES2022-P4Filtered.json.gz
Both files are compressed using gnu zip (gzip)

title: Affective Support Data
text:
This data subset contains just the data from the pretest and posttest questionnaires.
Posttest columns are marked with either .ect or .pot depending on which posttest the items appear on. Note that students received the ECT and POT tests on Wednesday or Friday of the study week depending on their treatment group.
Pre, Post Data

title: Affective Support Data
text:
These data contain information on how the learning supports were played. * Timestamp_XXX – These give the time at which the level was played. * TrophyLevel_XXX – what trophy the player earned. This can be gold, silver, quit or missing. The quit indicates that the player attempted the level but did not earn a trophy. * NumberAttempts_XXX – The number of attempts the player made for this game level.
Note that the player may have attempted each level several times. There are two versions of this data file, one showing the values related to the first level and one to the last levels. In the full data set the suffixes .first and .last are added to the column names to indicate which version is used.

Observables, First Attempt
Observables, Last Attempt

text:
This is data about the usage of the learning supports.
Learning Support

The EAP (expected a posteriori) scores are produced by assigning Low=-1, Medium=0 and High=1 and calculating the expected value.

title: Untitled
text:
Parameters

columns <- "[ 30, 70 ]"
figwidth <- "300"


head <- 
  "---
title: \"Personnel\"
editor: 
  markdown: 
    wrap: 72
---
"
foot <- 
  "
  "


ord <- c("Lead Investigators","Affective Support",
"Before/After Study", "Alumni")

title: Untitled
text:
Build-it

if (file.exists("Personnel.qmd")) 
  file.remove("Personnel.qmd")

[1] TRUE

pfile <- file("Personnel.qmd")
open(pfile,open="wt")
cat(head,file=pfile)


for (sec in ord) {
  cat("\n\n##",sec,"\n\n",file=pfile)
  cat(":::: { layout = ",dQuote(columns,FALSE),"}\n\n",
      file=pfile)
  
  for (pp in grep(sec,persons$`Project group`)) {
    cat("::: {#first-column}\n",file=pfile)
    
    cat("![",persons$Name[pp],",",
        persons$`University abbrv`[pp],"]",
        "(",persons$`Photo link`[pp],")\n",
        sep="", file=pfile)
    
    cat(":::\n",file=pfile)
    cat("::: {#second-column}\n",file=pfile)
    
    cat("\n* ",persons$Name[pp],"\n",file=pfile)
    cat("*", persons$University[pp],"\n",file=pfile)
    cat("* **Role:** ",persons$`Role in the project`[pp],
        "\n",file=pfile)
    if (!is.na(persons$Homepage[pp]))
      cat("* **Homepage:** <",persons$Homepage[pp],
          ">\n",sep="",file=pfile)
    cat("* **Google Scholar:** <",
        persons$`Google Scholar`[pp],">\n",
        sep="",file=pfile)
    if (!is.na(persons$`Other links`[pp]))
      cat("* ",persons$`Other links`[pp],"\n",file=pfile)
    cat(":::\n\n",file=pfile)  
  }
  cat("::::\n\n",file=pfile)
}


cat(foot,file=pfile)
close(pfile)

title: Event Logs
text:
Events are stored in the Proc 4 format (ralmond2019a?). It is converted from the xAPI (xAPI?) format using in Learning Locker (LearningLocker?) by the dongle code in the Proc4 (Proc4?) package. In particular, it means that messages are identified by (verb, object) pairs (xAPI-style) not single mess strings (Proc4-style)
The JSON format is as follows:

{
  app: "ecd://epls.coe.fsu.edu/PhysicsPlayground/IES/Fall22/BigStudy",  /* Fixed String */
  uid: "[A-F]0000",
  context: "Game Level",
  sender: "PP Learning Locker",  /* Fixed String */
  verb: <<see event vocabulary>>, 
  object <<see event vocabulary>>, 
  timestamp: POSIX time string, /* When event was logged. */
  processed: logical,  /* For internal EI use */
  pErr: string, /* Error code from processing (if any) */
  data: { <<Arbitrary JSON document>>}
}

The app and sender strings are constant, so are probably not interesting.
The first character of the uid gives the study condition.
